item.title: PhD defence
item.description: I defended my PhD titled “Design and Security Analysis of Lattice-based Post-Quantum Encryption” on May 28th. My PhD thesis can be found [here]. A recording of my defence can be found [here]. This presentation is aimed at a broad audience and should be followable without background knowledge.

item.title: Other projects
item.description: Engineering and science communications have always been passions of mine. However, I’m always looking forward to broaden my horizon with new and challenging projects. A non-exhaustive (and quite random) list of projects and experiences in which I took part can be found below. Exploitation of research: technology & knowledge transfer: 5 days training on research valorisation by KU Leuven Research & Development (LRD), including sessions on intellectual property law, industry collaboration and exploitation plans and with a hands-on project on validation of research results.

item.title: Science Communication
item.description: Wetenschapsbattle / Battle of the Scientists: Science communication challenge: present your research to children age 6-12. I was selected of one of the five finalists and presented my work to an audience of 3500 children. item.title: About me
item.description: I’m a post-doctoral researcher in the COSIC research group at KU Leuven, Belgium. My research interests include development, security and side-channel secure implementation of post-quantum encryption. I’m involved in the development of the encryption algorithm Saber, which is one of the candidates for standardization in the NIST post-quantum standardization process. That was gobbledigook to me, now in human language? Cryptography is the study of secure communication, for example encrypting messages into a secret code.
